import Mathlib

/- Let $X \in M_n(\mathbb{R})$ be a matrix such that $\text{tr}(X^k) = 0$ for all $1 \le k \le n$. Prove that $X^n = O_n$. -/
theorem algebra_7220 {n : ℕ} {X : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) ℝ} (h : ∀ k ∈ Finset.Icc 1 n, (X ^ k).trace = 0) :
    X ^ n = 0 := by

soln_description: We have N/915! = 915C915 + 916C915 + ... + 1980C915. But 915C915 = 916C916 and 916C916 + 916C915 = 917C916. Then 917C916 + 917C915 = 918C916 and so on. So N/915! = 1981C916. Hence 916N = 1981!/1065! = 1981·1980 ... 1066. Note that 2·916 = 1832 appears on the rhs, so for any n ≠ 1832 (and 1065 < n < 1982) we certainly have n a factor of N. But the rhs includes the factors 1603 = 7·229, 1600 = 4·400 and 1832. Hence we can divide through by 916 = 4·229 and conclude that N is also divisible by 1832. s are also available in Australian Mathematical Olympiads 1979-1995 by H Lausch and P J Taylor, ISBN 0858896451, published by Australian Mathematics Trust, can be ordered by email. 2nd Aus 1981 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 28 Oct 2003 Last updated/corrected 28 Oct 03
informal_statement: 2nd Australian 1981 Problem B1 Let N = 915! + 916!/1! + 917!/2! + ... + 1980!/1065! Show that if 1065 < n < 1982, then n divides N.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- 2nd Australian 1981 Problem B1 Let N = 915! + 916!/1! + 917!/2! + ... + 1980!/1065! Show that if 1065 < n < 1982, then n divides N. -/
theorem number_theory_121591 : ∀ n : ℕ, 1065 < n ∧ n < 1982 → n ∣ ∑ i ∈ Icc 915 1980, (Nat.factorial i) / (Nat.factorial (i - 915)) := by

soln_description:
[Solution] Let $f(x)=\frac{1}{x^{2}-1}$, then when $|x|>1$, $f(x)$ takes all positive real numbers; when $|x|<1$, $f(x) \leqslant-1$.
That is, the range of $f(x)$ is $(-\infty,-1] \cup(0,+\infty)$.
$\therefore \quad y \in\left(-\frac{\pi}{2},-\frac{\pi}{4}\right] \cup\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
Therefore, the correct choice is $(D)$.
informal_statement:
7.18 The range of the function $y=\operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{x^{2}-1}$ is
(A) $\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(B) $\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(C) $\left(-\frac{\pi}{2},-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \cup\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(D) $\left(-\frac{\pi}{2},-\frac{\pi}{4}\right] \cup\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(2nd "Hope Cup" National Mathematics Invitational Competition, 1991)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 7.18 The range of the function $y=\operatorname{arctg} \frac{1}{x^{2}-1}$ is
(A) $\left(-\frac{\pi}{2}, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(B) $\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(C) $\left(-\frac{\pi}{2},-\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \cup\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(D) $\left(-\frac{\pi}{2},-\frac{\pi}{4}\right] \cup\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$.
(2nd "Hope Cup" National Mathematics Invitational Competition, 1991) -/
theorem calculus_192875 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (hf : f = λ x => arctan (1 / (x^2 - 1))) :
    range f = {y | -π/2 < y ∧ y ≤ -π/4 ∨ 0 < y ∧ y < π/2} := by

soln_description:
For $n \geqslant 2$, we have
$$
n^{2}-2 n(n-1) \leqslant 0 \text {. }
$$

For any $t>0$, we have
$$
\begin{array}{c}
n(n-1) \\
2
\end{array} t^{2}-n t+1 \geqslant 0 .
$$

From this, we get $\left.(1+t)^{n} \geqslant 1+n t+\frac{n(n}{2} 1\right) t^{2} \geqslant 2 n t$.
$$
\text { When } x>\max \left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{\text {口 }}\right) \text {, since } f(x)
$$

is a polynomial with the leading coefficient of 1, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x+1)=\left(1+x-b_{1}\right) \cdot\left(1+x \quad b_{2}\right) \\
\text { - ... }\left(1+x-b_{0}\right)>0 \text {. } \\
\end{array}
$$

By the AM-GM inequality, we have
$$
\begin{array}{l}
f(x+1) \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x-b_{i}} \\
\geqslant n f(x+1) \sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x-b_{1}}} \\
=n \sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{n} \cdot \frac{\left(1+x-b_{1}\right)^{n}}{x-b_{i}}} .
\end{array}
$$

From (1), we get $\frac{\left(1+x-b_{1}\right)^{n}}{x-b_{1}} \geqslant 2 n$.
Therefore, $f(x+1) \sum_{j=1}^{n} \frac{1}{x-b} \geq 2 n^{2}$.
Thus, the original inequality holds.
informal_statement:
Let the real-coefficient polynomial be
$$
f(x)=x^{\mathrm{n}}+a_{1} x^{\mathrm{n}-1}+\cdots+a_{\mathrm{n}}
$$

with roots being real numbers $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$, where $n \geqslant 2$.
Prove: For $x>\max \left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{\mathrm{n}}\right)$,
$$
f(x+1) \geqslant \frac{2 n^{2}}{\frac{1}{x-b_{1}}+\frac{1}{x}+\cdots+\frac{1}{b_{2}}+\cdots b_{n}}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Polynomial

/- Let the real-coefficient polynomial be
$$
f(x)=x^{\mathrm{n}}+a_{1} x^{\mathrm{n}-1}+\cdots+a_{\mathrm{n}}
$$

with roots being real numbers $b_{1}, b_{2}, \ldots, b_{n}$, where $n \geqslant 2$.
Prove: For $x>\max \left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{\mathrm{n}}\right)$,
$$
f(x+1) \geqslant \frac{2 n^{2}}{\frac{1}{x-b_{1}}+\frac{1}{x}+\cdots+\frac{1}{b_{2}}+\cdots b_{n}}
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_315771 {n : ℕ} (hn : n ≥ 2) (f : Polynomial ℝ)
    (hf : f.degree = n) (b : Fin n → ℝ) (hb : ∀ i, f.eval (b i) = 0) :
    ∀ x, x > sSup {b i | i} → f.eval (x + 1) ≥ 2 * n ^ 2 / ∑ i, 1 / (x - b i) := by

soln_description:
7. A.

According to the problem, let $z=\overline{a b c a b c}$. Then $z=1001 \times \overline{a b c}=7 \times 11 \times 13 \times \overline{a b c}$.
informal_statement:
7. Let $z$ be a six-digit positive integer, where the first three digits are the same as the last three digits and in the same order (for example, 247 247). Which of the following numbers ( ) must be a divisor of $z$.
(A) 11
(B) 19
(C) 101
(D) 111
(E) 1111
informal_proof:
Let $z$ be a positive integer such that $100000 \leq z \leq 999999$. Let the integer formed by the first three digits of $z$ be denoted by $a$, and the integer formed by the last three digits be denoted by $b$. In terms of integer arithmetic, we have $a = z / 1000$ (integer division) and $b = z \pmod{1000}$. The structure of $z$ can therefore be expressed as $z = 1000a + b$.

The given condition is that the first three digits are the same as the last three digits, which means $a = b$. We can see this from the formal hypothesis $(z / 1000) \pmod{1000} = z \pmod{1000}$. The left-hand side is $a \pmod{1000}$. Since $z$ is a six-digit number, $a$ must be between 100 and 999, which implies $a \pmod{1000} = a$. The right-hand side is $b$. Thus, the hypothesis simplifies to $a = b$.

Substituting $b = a$ into the expression for $z$, we get:
$z = 1000a + a = 1001a$.

This equation shows that $z$ is a multiple of 1001. We now want to show that $z$ is divisible by 11. We observe that 1001 can be factored as:
$1001 = 11 \times 91$.

Substituting this factorization back into our expression for $z$:
$z = (11 \times 91)a = 11 \times (91a)$.

Since $a$ is an integer, $91a$ is also an integer. The expression shows that $z$ is equal to 11 multiplied by an integer. By the definition of divisibility, this means that 11 divides $z$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 7. Let $z$ be a six-digit positive integer, where the first three digits are the same as the last three digits and in the same order (for example, 247 247). Which of the following numbers ( ) must be a divisor of $z$.
(A) 11
(B) 19
(C) 101
(D) 111
(E) 1111 -/
theorem number_theory_318880 (z : ℕ) (hz : z ∈ Finset.Icc 100000 999999) (h : (z / 1000) % 1000 = z % 1000) :
    11 ∣ z := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_318880 (z : ℕ) (hz : z ∈ Finset.Icc 100000 999999) (h : (z / 1000) % 1000 = z % 1000) :
    11 ∣ z := by
  rw [Finset.mem_Icc] at hz
  rcases hz with ⟨hz1, hz2⟩
  have h2 : z = 1001 * (z / 1000) := by 
    omega
  rw [h2] at *
  have : 11 ∣ 1001 * (z / 1000) := by 
    have : 1001 * (z / 1000) = 11 * (91 * (z / 1000)) := by 
      omega
    rw [this]
    exact ⟨91 * (z / 1000), by ring⟩
  exact this

soln_description:
Analyzing the inequality, which is homogeneous in $a, b, c$, we can assume $a+b+c=1$ or $ab+bc+ca=1$ or $abc=1$, but we find that assuming $ab+bc+ca=1$ is the best. Thus, the original problem becomes:
Given $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}$, and $ab+bc+ca=1$. Prove that $\left(a^{2}+ab+b^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}+bc+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}+ca+a^{2}\right) \geqslant 1$.
Proof: Since $a^{2}+ab+b^{2}=\frac{1}{2} a^{2}+\frac{2 ab}{2}+\frac{1}{2} b^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right)$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
=\frac{1}{2}(a+b)^{2}+\frac{1}{2}\left(a^{2}+b^{2}\right) \\
\geqslant \frac{1}{2}(a+b)^{2}+\frac{1}{4}(a+b)^{2}=\frac{3}{4}(a+b)^{2},
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, it suffices to prove $\Pi \frac{3}{4}(a+b)^{2} \geqslant 1$.
In $\triangle ABC$, we have
$$
\tan \frac{A}{2} \cdot \tan \frac{B}{2}+\tan \frac{B}{2} \cdot \tan \frac{C}{2}+\tan \frac{C}{2} \cdot \tan \frac{A}{2}=1 .
$$

Let $a=\tan \frac{A}{2}, b=\tan \frac{B}{2}, c=\tan \frac{C}{2}$.
It suffices to prove $\Pi \frac{3}{4}\left(\tan \frac{A}{2}+\tan \frac{B}{2}\right)^{2} \geqslant 1$, i.e.,
$$
\begin{aligned}
& \prod\left(\tan \frac{A}{2}+\tan \frac{B}{2}\right)^{2} \geqslant \frac{64}{27} \\
\Leftrightarrow & \prod\left(\frac{\sin \frac{A}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{B}{2}+\sin \frac{B}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{A}{2}}{\cos \frac{A}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{B}{2}}\right)^{2} \geqslant \frac{64}{27} \\
\Leftrightarrow & \prod\left(\frac{\cos \frac{C}{2}}{\cos \frac{A}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{B}{2}}\right)^{2} \geqslant \frac{64}{27} \\
\Leftrightarrow & \prod \frac{1}{\cos \frac{A}{2}} \geqslant \frac{8}{3 \sqrt{3}} \Leftrightarrow \prod \cos \frac{A}{2} \leqslant \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{8} .
\end{aligned}
$$

And $\cos \frac{A}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{B}{2} \cdot \cos \frac{C}{2} \leqslant\left(\frac{\cos \frac{A}{2}+\cos \frac{B}{2}+\cos \frac{C}{2}}{3}\right)^{3}$
$$
\leqslant\left(\cos \frac{\frac{A}{2}+\frac{B}{2}+\frac{C}{2}}{3}\right)^{3}=\left(\cos \frac{\pi}{6}\right)^{3}=\frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{8} .
$$

Therefore, the inequality to be proven holds.
informal_statement:
Example 8 Let $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$. Prove:
$$
\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}+b c+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}+c a+a^{2}\right) \geqslant(a b+b c+c a)^{2} .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 8 Let $a, b, c \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$. Prove:
$$
\left(a^{2}+a b+b^{2}\right)\left(b^{2}+b c+c^{2}\right)\left(c^{2}+c a+a^{2}\right) \geqslant(a b+b c+c a)^{2} .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_220055 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    (a^2 + a * b + b^2) * (b^2 + b * c + c^2) * (c^2 + c * a + a^2) ≥
    (a * b + b * c + c * a)^2 := by

soln_description:
17. Such a function exists.

Take $\alpha=\frac{\sqrt{5}+1}{2}, \beta=\frac{\sqrt{5}-1}{2}$, and let $f(n)=[a n+\beta]$ (denoting the integer part of $a n+\beta$), $n \in \mathbf{N}^{+}$. It can be proven that $f(n)$ satisfies the condition $f: \mathbf{N}^{\top} \rightarrow \mathbf{N}^{+}$, and $f(1)=[\alpha+\beta]=[\sqrt{5}]=2$.
$$
\begin{aligned}
f(n+1) & =[(n+1) \alpha+\beta]=[\alpha n+\beta+\alpha] \geqslant[\alpha n+\beta+1]=f(n)+1>f(n), \\
f(f(n)) & =[\alpha[\alpha n+\beta]+\beta]=[\alpha n+\beta]+[\beta[\alpha n+\beta]+\beta] \\
& =f(n)+[\beta[\alpha n+\beta]+\beta] .
\end{aligned}
$$

Clearly, $\alpha n+\beta$ is not an integer, so we have
$$
\begin{array}{c}
\beta[\alpha n+\beta]+\beta>\beta(\alpha n+\beta-1)+\beta=n+\beta^{2}>n,
\end{array}
$$

Thus, from (*) we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
{[\beta[\alpha n+\beta]+\beta]=n .} \\
f(f(n))=f(n)+n .
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, $f(n)=[\alpha n+\beta]$ satisfies all the conditions.
Note: The function $f(n)$ is not unique; there are multiple constructions, such as: $f(n)=\left[\frac{\sqrt{5}+1}{2} n+\frac{1}{2}\right], f(1)=2, f(n)=$ $n+\max \{i<n, f(i) \leqslant n\}$. It can be verified that these satisfy the conditions given in the problem.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 17. (1993 25th IMO Problem) Prove whether there exists a function $f: \mathbf{N}^{+} \rightarrow \mathbf{N}^{+}$,
(1) such that $f(1)=2$;
(2) $f[f(n)]=f(n)+n$ for all $n \in \mathbf{N}^{+}$;
(3) $f(n)<f(n+1)$ for all $n \in \mathbf{N}^{+}$. -/
theorem number_theory_199825 :
    ∃ f : ℕ+ → ℕ+, (f 1 = 2) ∧ (∀ n, f (f n) = f n + n) ∧ (∀ n, f n < f (n + 1)) := by

import Mathlib

/- \section*{Exercise 6 - 151046}

Let \(f\) be a function defined for all real numbers \(x\). It is assumed that \(f\) is zero-free, i.e., there is no real number \(x\) such that \(f(x)=0\).

Investigate whether it follows from this assumption that the function \(F\) defined by \(F(x)=f(2x)+f(3x)\) for all real numbers \(x\) is also zero-free! -/
theorem algebra_186820 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (h : ∀ x, f x ≠ 0) :
    ∀ x, (f (2 * x) + f (3 * x)) ≠ 0 := by

informal_proof:
We are given that $x^2 - 3x + 1 = 0$ and $x \neq 0$. Our goal is to find the value of $k$ given by the equation $\frac{1}{x^4} - \frac{7}{x^2} = k$.

First, we can rearrange the given quadratic equation to express $x^2$ in terms of $x$. By adding $3x - 1$ to both sides of $x^2 - 3x + 1 = 0$, we obtain:
$$x^2 = 3x - 1$$

Since we are given that $x \neq 0$, we can divide the initial equation $x^2 - 3x + 1 = 0$ by $x$ to get $x - 3 + \frac{1}{x} = 0$. Rearranging this gives an expression for $\frac{1}{x}$:
$$\frac{1}{x} = 3 - x$$

Now, we can find an expression for $\frac{1}{x^2}$. We square the expression for $\frac{1}{x}$:
$$ \frac{1}{x^2} = \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)^2 = (3 - x)^2 = 9 - 6x + x^2 $$
We substitute our expression for $x^2$:
$$ \frac{1}{x^2} = 9 - 6x + (3x - 1) = 8 - 3x $$

Next, we find an expression for $\frac{1}{x^4}$. We square the expression for $\frac{1}{x^2}$:
$$ \frac{1}{x^4} = \left(\frac{1}{x^2}\right)^2 = (8 - 3x)^2 = 64 - 48x + 9x^2 $$
Again, we substitute the expression for $x^2$:
$$ \frac{1}{x^4} = 64 - 48x + 9(3x - 1) = 64 - 48x + 27x - 9 = 55 - 21x $$

Finally, we substitute these results into the equation for $k$:
$$ k = \frac{1}{x^4} - \frac{7}{x^2} = (55 - 21x) - 7(8 - 3x) $$
Distributing the $-7$, we get:
$$ k = 55 - 21x - 56 + 21x $$
The terms involving $x$ cancel out:
$$ k = 55 - 56 = -1 $$
Thus, the value of $k$ is $-1$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- If ${{x}^{2}}-3x+1=0$ and $\frac{1}{{{x}^{4}}}-\frac{7}{{{x}^{2}}}=k$, find the value of $k$.
 -/
theorem algebra_3278 {x k : ℝ} (hx1 : x^2 - 3 * x + 1 = 0) (hx2 : x ≠ 0) (h : 1 / x^4 - 7 / x^2 = k) : k = -1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_3278 {x k : ℝ} (hx1 : x^2 - 3 * x + 1 = 0) (hx2 : x ≠ 0) (h : 1 / x^4 - 7 / x^2 = k) : k = -1 := by
  have h1 : x^2 = 3 * x - 1 := by
    linarith
  have h2 : x + 1 / x = 3 := by
    field_simp [hx2]
    nlinarith
  have h3 : 1 / x^2 = 8 - 3 * x := by
    have hx5 : 1 / x = 3 - x := by
      field_simp [hx2]
      nlinarith
    -- use field_simp
    calc
      1 / x^2 = (1 / x) ^ 2 := by ring_nf
      _ = (3 - x) ^ 2 := by rw [hx5]
      _ = 8 - 3 * x := by
        nlinarith [h1]
  have h4 : 1 / x^4 = 55 - 21 * x := by
    calc
      1 / x^4 = (1 / x^2)^2 := by ring_nf
      _ = (8 - 3 * x) ^ 2 := by rw [h3]
      _ = 55 - 21 * x := by
        have hx2' : x^2 = 3 * x - 1 := h1
        nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 3)]
  -- Now compute the expression
  have h5 : 1 / x^4 - 7 / x^2 = -1 := by
    have eq1 : 1 / x^4 = 55 - 21 * x := h4
    have eq2 : 1 / x^2 = 8 - 3 * x := h3
    -- need to rewrite
    have eq3 : 7 / x^2 = 7 * (8 - 3 * x) := by
      rw [show 7 / x^2 = 7 * (1 / x^2) by ring]
      rw [eq2]
      all_goals nlinarith
    -- need to compute
    have eq4 : 1 / x^4 - 7 / x^2 = (55 - 21 * x) - 7 * (8 - 3 * x) := by
      rw [show 1 / x^4 - 7 / x^2 = (1 / x^4) - 7 / x^2 by rfl]
      rw [eq1, eq3]
      all_goals nlinarith
    nlinarith [eq4]
  -- Now for the final step
  linarith [h, h5]

informal_statement: Given that when $x \in [1, \text{e}]$, the inequality $a \ln x \leqslant -\frac{1}{2} x^2 + (a+1)x$ always holds, find the range of the real number $a$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Given that when $x \in [1, \text{e}]$, the inequality $a \ln x \leqslant -\frac{1}{2} x^2 + (a+1)x$ always holds, find the range of the real number $a$. -/
theorem inequalities_11754 (a : ℝ) :
  ∀ x ∈ Icc 1 (exp 1), a * log x ≤ -1 / 2 * x ^ 2 + (a + 1) * x ↔
  a ≤ (exp 2 - 2 * exp 1) / (2 * (exp 1 - 1)) := by

informal_statement: Let $n$ be a positive odd integer, and let $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ be any permutation of the positive integers $1, 2, \ldots, n$. Prove that the product $(a_1 - 1)(a_2^2 - 2) \cdots (a_n^n - n)$ is even.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- Let $n$ be a positive odd integer, and let $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$ be any permutation of the positive integers $1, 2, \ldots, n$. Prove that the product $(a_1 - 1)(a_2^2 - 2) \cdots (a_n^n - n)$ is even. -/
theorem number_theory_8299 {n : ℕ} (hn : Odd n) (a : Equiv.Perm (Fin n)) :
    Even (∏ i : Fin n, ((a i + 1) ^ (i.1 + 1) - (i.1 + 1))) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Let $d$ be the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$, and define

$$
p=\frac{a}{d}, \quad q=\frac{b}{d}
$$

The numbers $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime natural numbers, and we have

$$
V(a, b)=V(p d, q d)=d V(p, q)=p q d
$$

Substituting this expression into the given equation, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
p^{2} d^{2} & =4 q d+3 p q d \\
p^{2} d & =4 q+3 p q \\
4 q & =p(p d-3 q)
\end{aligned}
$$

From the last equation, it follows that $p \mid 4 q$. Since $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime, it must be that $p \mid 4$. Therefore, we have three cases: $p=1, p=2$, or $p=4$.

Consider the first case $p=1$. Substituting, we get $d=7 q$. Direct verification shows that for any natural number $q$, the numbers $a=7 q$ and $b=7 q^{2}$ indeed satisfy the condition of the problem.

If $p=2$, substituting gives $2 d=5 q$, implying that $q$ is even. However, in this case, both $p$ and $q$ are even, which contradicts the fact that $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime. Therefore, there are no such $a$ and $b$ in this case.

If $p=4$, we get $16 d=16 q$, or $d=q$. Since $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime, $q$ must not be even. Direct verification shows that for any odd natural number $q$, the numbers $a=4 q$ and $b=q^{2}$ indeed satisfy the condition of the problem.

Finally, all solutions $(a, b)$ to the original equation are $\left(7 q, 7 q^{2}\right)$, for any natural number $q$, and $\left(4 q, q^{2}\right)$, for any odd natural number $q$.

soln_description:
Answer 1.
Analysis Let $x=0$, we get $a_{0}=4^{2 n}$; by letting $x=1$ and $x=-1$ respectively, and adding the two resulting equations, we get
$$
a_{0}+a_{2}+a_{4}+\cdots+a_{2 n}=\frac{1}{2}\left(6^{2 n}+2^{2 n}\right)
$$

Therefore,
$$
a_{2}+a_{4}+\cdots+a_{2 n}=\frac{1}{2}\left(6^{2 n}+2^{2 n}\right)-4^{2 n}=2^{2 n-1}\left(3^{2 n}+1\right)-4^{2 n}=(-1)^{2 n-1} \times 1-1^{2 n}=-2=1 \quad(\bmod 3)
$$

soln_description:
［Proof］ From the assumption, we have
$$
3 a_{k-1}=2\left(k a_{k-1}-k a_{k}\right), \quad k=2,3,4, \cdots
$$

Thus,
$$
\begin{aligned}
3 \sum_{k=2}^{n+1} a_{k-1} & =2 \sum_{k=2}^{n+1} k a_{k-1}-2 \sum_{k=2}^{n+1} k a_{k} \\
& =2 \sum_{k=1}^{n}(k+1) a_{k}-2 \sum_{k=2}^{n} k a_{k}-2(n+1) a_{n+1} \\
& =2 a_{1}+2 \sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}-2(n+1) a_{n+1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

From this, we obtain
$$
\sum_{k=1}^{n} a_{k}=2 a_{1}-2(n+1) a_{n+1}<1 .
$$

soln_description:
## Solution

By the definition of the limit:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \forall \varepsilon>0: \exists N(\varepsilon) \in \mathbb{N}: \forall n: n \geq N(\varepsilon):\left|a_{n}-a\right| \\
& \left|\frac{10-15 n^{2}+12+15 n^{2}}{5\left(4+5 n^{2}\right)}\right| \\
& \left.\frac{22}{5\left(4+5 n^{2}\right)} \right\rvert\, \\
& \frac{22}{5\left(4+5 n^{2}\right)} \\
& 4+5 n^{2}>\frac{22}{5 \varepsilon} ;=> \\
& n^{2}>\frac{1}{5}\left(\frac{22}{5 \varepsilon}-4\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The last inequality will also hold if we transition to a stronger inequality.

$$
n>\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}\left|\frac{22}{5 \varepsilon}-4\right|}
$$

It is clear that the limit exists and is equal to $-\frac{3}{5}$.

From (*) it is easy to calculate $N(\varepsilon)$:

$$
N(\varepsilon)=\left[\sqrt{\frac{1}{5}\left|\frac{22}{5 \varepsilon}-4\right|}\right]+1
$$

soln_description:
To find the last three digits of the product \(1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot \ldots \cdot 2009 \cdot 2011\), we need to compute this product modulo 1000. 

1. **Identify the sequence and its properties:**
   The sequence is the product of all odd numbers from 1 to 2011. This can be written as:
   \[
   P = 1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \cdot \ldots \cdot 2009 \cdot 2011
   \]

2. **Modulo 8:**
   We first compute the product modulo 8. Notice that the sequence of odd numbers modulo 8 repeats every 4 terms:
   \[
   1, 3, 5, 7 \equiv 1, 3, 5, -1 \pmod{8}
   \]
   The product of one such block is:
   \[
   1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 \equiv 1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot (-1) \equiv -15 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}
   \]
   There are 1006 odd numbers from 1 to 2011, so there are 251 such blocks:
   \[
   (1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7)^{251} \equiv 1^{251} \equiv 1 \pmod{8}
   \]
   The last term, 2011, is:
   \[
   2011 \equiv 3 \pmod{8}
   \]
   Therefore, the product modulo 8 is:
   \[
   1 \cdot 3 \equiv 3 \pmod{8}
   \]

3. **Modulo 125:**
   Since 125 is a factor of 1000, we need to check if the product contains any multiples of 5. Clearly, the product contains many multiples of 5 (e.g., 5, 15, 25, etc.), and thus:
   \[
   P \equiv 0 \pmod{125}
   \]

4. **Combine results using the Chinese Remainder Theorem:**
   We have:
   \[
   P \equiv 3 \pmod{8}
   \]
   \[
   P \equiv 0 \pmod{125}
   \]
   We need to find \(x\) such that:
   \[
   x \equiv 3 \pmod{8}
   \]
   \[
   x \equiv 0 \pmod{125}
   \]
   Let \(x = 125k\). Then:
   \[
   125k \equiv 3 \pmod{8}
   \]
   Since \(125 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}\), we have:
   \[
   5k \equiv 3 \pmod{8}
   \]
   To solve for \(k\), we find the multiplicative inverse of 5 modulo 8. The inverse of 5 modulo 8 is 5, since:
   \[
   5 \cdot 5 = 25 \equiv 1 \pmod{8}
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   k \equiv 3 \cdot 5 \equiv 15 \equiv 7 \pmod{8}
   \]
   So:
   \[
   k = 8m + 7 \text{ for some integer } m
   \]
   Thus:
   \[
   x = 125k = 125(8m + 7) = 1000m + 875
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   x \equiv 875 \pmod{1000}
   \]

The final answer is \(\boxed{875}\).
informal_statement: Find the last three digits in the product $1 \cdot 3\cdot  5\cdot 7 \cdot  . . . \cdot  2009 \cdot  2011$.
informal_proof:
We want to find the last three digits of the product $P = 1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot \ldots \cdot 2011$. This is equivalent to computing the value of $P$ modulo 1000. We will use the Chinese Remainder Theorem, noting that $1000 = 8 \times 125$ and that 8 and 125 are coprime. We will compute the product modulo 125 and modulo 8 separately.

**1. Computation modulo 125**

The product $P$ is the product of all odd integers from 1 to 2011. This sequence of factors includes many multiples of 5. For instance, the terms 5, 15, and 25 are all present in the product. Let's consider the sub-product of just these three terms:
$5 \cdot 15 \cdot 25 = 5 \cdot (3 \cdot 5) \cdot (5^2) = 3 \cdot 5^4 = 3 \cdot 625$.
Since $625 = 5 \cdot 125$, this sub-product is divisible by 125. As this sub-product is a factor of the total product $P$, it follows that $P$ must also be divisible by 125.
Therefore, we have:
$P \equiv 0 \pmod{125}$.

**2. Computation modulo 8**

The product is $P = \prod_{i=0}^{1005} (2i+1)$, which contains $1006$ terms.
Let's examine the sequence of terms modulo 8:
$1, 3, 5, 7, 9 \equiv 1, 11 \equiv 3, 13 \equiv 5, \ldots$
The sequence of odd numbers modulo 8 is periodic with period 4: $(1, 3, 5, 7)$.
Let's find the product of one such block of four consecutive odd numbers:
$1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \cdot 7 = 105$.
Modulo 8, $105 = 13 \cdot 8 + 1$, so $105 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.
The product of any four consecutive odd numbers is congruent to 1 modulo 8.

Our product has 1006 terms. We can group these terms into blocks of four.
$1006 = 4 \times 251 + 2$.
So, the product consists of 251 blocks of four terms, followed by two remaining terms. The product of the 251 blocks is congruent to $1^{251} \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.
Thus, the value of $P$ modulo 8 is determined by the product of the last two terms in the sequence. The last two terms are $2009$ and $2011$.
$2009 = 251 \cdot 8 + 1 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.
$2011 = 251 \cdot 8 + 3 \equiv 3 \pmod 8$.
The product of these last two terms modulo 8 is $1 \cdot 3 \equiv 3 \pmod 8$.
Therefore, we have:
$P \equiv 1^{251} \cdot (2009 \cdot 2011) \equiv 1 \cdot (1 \cdot 3) \equiv 3 \pmod 8$.

**3. Combining the results**

We have derived the following system of congruences for $P$:
1. $P \equiv 0 \pmod{125}$
2. $P \equiv 3 \pmod 8$

From the first congruence, we know that $P$ must be a multiple of 125. So, $P = 125k$ for some integer $k$.
Substituting this into the second congruence:
$125k \equiv 3 \pmod 8$.

To solve for $k$, we first reduce 125 modulo 8:
$125 = 15 \cdot 8 + 5$, so $125 \equiv 5 \pmod 8$.
The congruence becomes:
$5k \equiv 3 \pmod 8$.

To isolate $k$, we need to find the multiplicative inverse of 5 modulo 8. By inspection, we see that $5 \cdot 5 = 25$, and $25 = 3 \cdot 8 + 1$, so $25 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$. Thus, the inverse of 5 modulo 8 is 5.
Multiplying both sides of the congruence by 5:
$5 \cdot (5k) \equiv 5 \cdot 3 \pmod 8$
$25k \equiv 15 \pmod 8$
$1k \equiv 7 \pmod 8$.
So, $k \equiv 7 \pmod 8$.

This means $k$ can be written in the form $k = 8m + 7$ for some integer $m$.
Substituting this back into our expression for $P$:
$P = 125k = 125(8m + 7) = 1000m + 125 \cdot 7$.
$P = 1000m + 875$.

This implies that $P \equiv 875 \pmod{1000}$.
Therefore, the last three digits of the product are 875.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset

/- Find the last three digits in the product $1 \cdot 3\cdot  5\cdot 7 \cdot  . . . \cdot  2009 \cdot  2011$.
 -/
theorem number_theory_30785 : (∏ i ∈ range 1006, (2 * i + 1)) % 1000 = 875 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Finset

theorem number_theory_30785 : (∏ i ∈ range 1006, (2 * i + 1)) % 1000 = 875 := by 
  native_decide

informal_statement: What is the sum of the digits of the product of $2002$ and the number consisting of $2000$ repeated $1$s, i.e., $111\ldots111$ where the digit $1$ is repeated $2000$ times?
informal_proof:
We want to find the sum of the digits of the number given by the expression $2002 \times \sum_{i=0}^{1999} 10^i$.

First, let's analyze the sum term. The sum $\sum_{i=0}^{1999} 10^i$ represents the number:
$$N = 10^0 + 10^1 + \dots + 10^{1999}$$
This is a geometric series which evaluates to the integer composed of 2000 digits, all of which are 1. That is, $N = \underbrace{11...1}_{2000 \text{ times}}$.

Next, we need to compute the product $P = 2002 \times N$. To make the multiplication simpler, we can factor $2002$ as $2 \times 1001$. So, we can write the product as:
$$P = 2 \times 1001 \times N = 2 \times (1000 + 1) \times N = 2 \times (1000N + N)$$

Let's compute the intermediate value $M = 1000N + N$.
The number $N$ is $\underbrace{11...1}_{2000}$.
The number $1000N$ is $N$ shifted three places to the left, which is equivalent to appending three zeros. So, $1000N = \underbrace{11...1}_{2000}000$.

We can find $M$ by performing the addition:
```
      000...000111...111  (N, which has 2000 digits)
+     111...111000...000  (1000N, which has 2003 digits)
-------------------------
```
Let's examine the sum digit by digit, from right to left:
- The last three digits (positions $10^0, 10^1, 10^2$) are determined by $1+0=1$. The result ends in $111$.
- The next 1997 digits (from position $10^3$ to $10^{1999}$) are determined by adding the digit 1 from $N$ and the digit 1 from $1000N$. The sum is $1+1=2$. This gives a sequence of 1997 twos.
- The first three digits (positions $10^{2000}, 10^{2001}, 10^{2002}$) are determined by $0+1=1$. The number begins with $111$.

Combining these results, the number $M$ is:
$$M = \underbrace{111}_{\text{3 digits}} \underbrace{22...2}_{1997 \text{ digits}} \underbrace{111}_{\text{3 digits}}$$

Now, we compute the final product, $P = 2 \times M$. Since all digits of $M$ are either 1 or 2, they are less than 5. Multiplying $M$ by 2 will therefore not produce any carries. We can find the digits of $P$ by simply multiplying each digit of $M$ by 2.
- The digits that are 1 in $M$ become $2 \times 1 = 2$ in $P$.
- The digits that are 2 in $M$ become $2 \times 2 = 4$ in $P$.

Thus, the number $P$ is:
$$P = \underbrace{222}_{\text{3 digits}} \underbrace{44...4}_{1997 \text{ digits}} \underbrace{222}_{\text{3 digits}}$$

Finally, we find the sum of the digits of $P$. The number $P$ has:
- Three digits of 2 at the beginning.
- 1997 digits of 4 in the middle.
- Three digits of 2 at the end.

The sum of its digits is:
$$ (3 \times 2) + (1997 \times 4) + (3 \times 2) = 6 + 7988 + 6 = 8000 $$

Therefore, the sum of the digits of the given number is 8000.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- What is the sum of the digits of the product of $2002$ and the number consisting of $2000$ repeated $1$s, i.e., $111\ldots111$ where the digit $1$ is repeated $2000$ times? -/
theorem number_theory_5174 :
  (Nat.digits 10 (2002 * ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 2000, 10^i)).sum = 8000 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_5174 :
  (Nat.digits 10 (2002 * ∑ i ∈ Finset.range 2000, 10^i)).sum = 8000 := by
  native_decide

soln_description:
11.39. Consider the function $g(\varphi)=2 \sin \frac{\varphi}{2} f(x)$. Using the identity

$$
2 \sin \frac{\varphi}{2} \cos k \varphi=\sin \left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right) \varphi-\sin \left(k-\frac{1}{2}\right) \varphi
$$

we obtain $g(\varphi)=a_{n} \sin (n+1 / 2) \varphi-h(\varphi)$, where

$$
h(\varphi)=\left(a_{n}-a_{n-1}\right) \sin \left(n-\frac{1}{2}\right) \varphi+\ldots+\left(a_{1}-a_{0}\right) \sin \frac{\varphi}{2}+a_{0} \sin \left(-\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)
$$

Moreover, $|h(\varphi)| \leqslant\left(a_{n}-a_{n-1}\right)+\ldots+\left(a_{1}-a_{0}\right)+a_{0}=a_{n}$. Furthermore, the numbers $\sin \frac{\varphi}{2}$ and $\sin \left(-\frac{\varphi}{2}\right)$ cannot both be equal to +1, so $|h(\varphi)|<a_{n}$. If $\sin (n+1 / 2) \varphi=1$, then $g(\varphi)>0$, and if $\sin (n+1 / 2) \varphi=-1$, then $g(\varphi)<0$.

Clearly, $\sin (n+1 / 2) \varphi= \pm 1$ when $(n+1 / 2) \varphi=\pi / 2+l \pi$, i.e., when $\varphi=\frac{1+2 l}{1+2 n} \pi$. Between each pair of consecutive points $\frac{1+2 l}{1+2 n} \pi$, where $l=0,1, \ldots, n$, there is exactly one root of the equation $g(\varphi)=0$. In total, we obtain $n$ roots, and $\varphi=0$ is not a root. Therefore, for all these points, the function $\sin \frac{\varphi}{2}$ does not vanish (if $0 \leqslant \varphi \leqslant \pi$, then $\sin \frac{\varphi}{2}$ vanishes only at $\varphi=0$), i.e., they are also roots of the trigonometric polynomial $f(\varphi)$.

## EQUATIONS IN INTEGERS

soln_description: 2. Consider the expression $E(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$, where $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$. Determine the numbers $a, b$ and $c$ knowing that $E(x) \in \mathbb{Q}$, for any $x \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \mathbb{Q}$ and $E(2013)=2013$.
informal_statement:
## Subject 2.

Consider the expression $E(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$, where $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$. Determine the numbers $a, b$, and $c$ knowing that $E(x) \in \mathbb{Q}$ for any $x \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \mathbb{Q}$ and $E(2013)=2013$.

Prof. Cosmin Nitu, Bucharest

| Details of the solution | Associated grading |
| :--- | :---: |
| $E(\sqrt{2})=2 a+b \sqrt{2}+c$ and $E(-\sqrt{2})=2 a-b \sqrt{2}+c$, so $E(\sqrt{2})-E(-\sqrt{2})=2 b \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$, | 3p |
| so $b \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$. Similarly, $b \sqrt{3} \in \mathbb{Q}$. If $b \neq 0$, we get $\frac{b \sqrt{3}}{b \sqrt{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} \in \mathbb{Q}$, which is false. Therefore, $b=0$. | 2p |
| $E(2 \sqrt{2})=8 a+c$ and $E(2 \sqrt{2})-4 \cdot E(2)=-3 c \in \mathbb{Q}$, so $c \in \mathbb{Q}$ and $a \in \mathbb{Q}$. | 2p |


| Since $E(\sqrt{2}+1)=3 a+c+2 a \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$, it follows that $a \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$. Since $a \in \mathbb{Q}$, we obtain $a=0$. | **1p** |
| :--- | :--- |
| Since $E(2013)=c$, it follows that $c=2013$. | **1p** |
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## Subject 2.

Consider the expression $E(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$, where $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$. Determine the numbers $a, b$, and $c$ knowing that $E(x) \in \mathbb{Q}$ for any $x \in \mathbb{R} \backslash \mathbb{Q}$ and $E(2013)=2013$.

Prof. Cosmin Nitu, Bucharest

| Details of the solution | Associated grading |
| :--- | :---: |
| $E(\sqrt{2})=2 a+b \sqrt{2}+c$ and $E(-\sqrt{2})=2 a-b \sqrt{2}+c$, so $E(\sqrt{2})-E(-\sqrt{2})=2 b \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$, | 3p |
| so $b \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$. Similarly, $b \sqrt{3} \in \mathbb{Q}$. If $b \neq 0$, we get $\frac{b \sqrt{3}}{b \sqrt{2}}=\sqrt{\frac{3}{2}} \in \mathbb{Q}$, which is false. Therefore, $b=0$. | 2p |
| $E(2 \sqrt{2})=8 a+c$ and $E(2 \sqrt{2})-4 \cdot E(2)=-3 c \in \mathbb{Q}$, so $c \in \mathbb{Q}$ and $a \in \mathbb{Q}$. | 2p |


| Since $E(\sqrt{2}+1)=3 a+c+2 a \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$, it follows that $a \sqrt{2} \in \mathbb{Q}$. Since $a \in \mathbb{Q}$, we obtain $a=0$. | **1p** |
| :--- | :--- |
| Since $E(2013)=c$, it follows that $c=2013$. | **1p** | -/
theorem algebra_118865 {a b c : ℝ} (ha : ∀ x : ℝ, Irrational x → ∃ q : ℚ, a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c = q)
    (h : a * 2013 ^ 2 + b * 2013 + c = 2013) :
    a = 0 ∧ b = 0 ∧ c = 2013 := by

soln_description: Solution. Let $h(x)=f(x)-g(x)=a x^{2}+b x+c$. From the equality $[f(x)]=[g(x)]$ it follows that $|h(x)|=|f(x)-g(x)| \leqslant 1$. However, a quadratic trinomial can take arbitrarily large values in modulus. Therefore, $a=0$. On the other hand, for $b \neq 0$ the value of $|b x+c|$ at the point $-c / b+2 / b$ is two, so $b=0$ as well. Thus, $f(x)=g(x)+c$. Suppose $c \neq 0$. We can assume that $c>0$ (otherwise, we will swap the polynomials $f$ and $g$). Consider an integer $n$ that is the value of the polynomial $f(x)$ at some point. Denote this point by $x_{0}$. Then $g\left(x_{0}\right)=f\left(x_{0}\right)-c<f\left(x_{0}\right)=n$ and, therefore, $\left[g\left(x_{0}\right)\right]<n=\left[f\left(x_{0}\right)\right]$.
informal_statement: 1. Quadratic trinomials $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are such that $[f(x)]=[g(x)]$ for all $x$. Prove that $f(x)=g(x)$ for all $x$. (Here $[a]$ denotes the integer part of $a$, that is, the greatest integer not exceeding $a$).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Quadratic trinomials $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are such that $[f(x)]=[g(x)]$ for all $x$. Prove that $f(x)=g(x)$ for all $x$. (Here $[a]$ denotes the integer part of $a$, that is, the greatest integer not exceeding $a$). -/
theorem algebra_224306 {a b c d e f : ℝ} (ha : a ≠ 0) (hb : b ≠ 0) (hc : c ≠ 0)
    (hd : d ≠ 0) (he : e ≠ 0) (hf : f ≠ 0) (h : ∀ x, ⌊a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c⌋ = ⌊d * x ^ 2 + e * x + f⌋) :
    a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c = d * x ^ 2 + e * x + f := by

soln_description:
【Solution】Solution: $1 \div 3=\frac{1}{3}$
$$
\begin{array}{l}
2 \div 4=\frac{1}{2} \\
3 \div 5=\frac{3}{5} \\
\frac{1}{3}: \frac{1}{2}: \frac{3}{5}=10: 15: 18
\end{array}
$$
1 hour 26 minutes $=86$ minutes
$$
\begin{array}{l}
86 \times \frac{18}{10+15+18} \\
=86 \times \frac{18}{43} \\
=36 \text { (minutes) } \\
=0.6 \text { (hours); }
\end{array}
$$

Answer: The lamb took 0.6 hours to travel the downhill road. Therefore, the answer is: 0.6.
informal_statement: 20. (6 points) A road consists of three sections: uphill, flat, and downhill, with the ratio of their distances being 1:2:3. The ratio of the speeds at which the little sheep passes through each section is 3:4:5, as shown in the figure. It is known that the little sheep took a total of 1 hour and 26 minutes to pass through the three sections. Then, the little sheep took $\qquad$ hours to pass through the downhill section.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 20. (6 points) A road consists of three sections: uphill, flat, and downhill, with the ratio of their distances being 1:2:3. The ratio of the speeds at which the little sheep passes through each section is 3:4:5, as shown in the figure. It is known that the little sheep took a total of 1 hour and 26 minutes to pass through the three sections. Then, the little sheep took $\qquad$ hours to pass through the downhill section. -/
theorem algebra_217168 (d1 d2 d3 : ℝ) (h₀ : d1 / d2 = 1 / 2) (h₁ : d2 / d3 = 1 / 3)
    (h₂ : 3 * d1 + 4 * d2 + 5 * d3 = 1 * 60 + 26) :
    5 * d3 = 0.6 * 60 := by

informal_statement: 78. Given $a, b, c > 0$, and $a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} = 1$, prove: $\frac{a}{b^{2} + 1} + \frac{b}{c^{2} + 1} + \frac{c}{a^{2} + 1} \geqslant \frac{3}{4}(a \sqrt{a} + b \sqrt{b} + c \sqrt{c})^{2} \cdot(2002$ Mediterranean Mathematical Olympiad Problem)

/- 78. Given $a, b, c > 0$, and $a^{2} + b^{2} + c^{2} = 1$, prove: $\frac{a}{b^{2} + 1} + \frac{b}{c^{2} + 1} + \frac{c}{a^{2} + 1} \geqslant \frac{3}{4}(a \sqrt{a} + b \sqrt{b} + c \sqrt{c})^{2} \cdot(2002$ Mediterranean Mathematical Olympiad Problem) -/
theorem inequalities_600587 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a^2 + b^2 + c^2 = 1) :
    a / (b^2 + 1) + b / (c^2 + 1) + c / (a^2 + 1) ≥

soln_description:
1. **Identify the roots of \( x^{2n} = 1 \):**
   The roots of the equation \( x^{2n} = 1 \) are the \( 2n \)-th roots of unity, which can be written as:
   \[
   e^{i \frac{2k\pi}{2n}} = e^{i \frac{k\pi}{n}} \quad \text{for} \quad k = 0, 1, 2, \ldots, 2n-1
   \]
   These roots are evenly spaced around the unit circle in the complex plane.

2. **Identify the roots in the first quadrant:**
   The first quadrant roots are those with arguments between \( 0 \) and \( \frac{\pi}{2} \). For \( x^{2n} = 1 \), these roots are:
   \[
   e^{i \frac{k\pi}{n}} \quad \text{for} \quad k = 1, 2, \ldots, \left\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \right\rfloor
   \]
   where \( \left\lfloor \cdot \right\rfloor \) denotes the floor function.

3. **Calculate the product of these roots:**
   - For odd \( n \):
     \[
     a_n = \prod_{k=1}^{\frac{n-1}{2}} e^{i \frac{k\pi}{n}} = e^{i \sum_{k=1}^{\frac{n-1}{2}} \frac{k\pi}{n}} = e^{i \frac{\pi}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{\frac{n-1}{2}} k}
     \]
     The sum of the first \( \frac{n-1}{2} \) integers is:
     \[
     \sum_{k=1}^{\frac{n-1}{2}} k = \frac{\left( \frac{n-1}{2} \right) \left( \frac{n+1}{2} \right)}{2} = \frac{(n-1)(n+1)}{8}
     \]
     Therefore:
     \[
     a_n = e^{i \frac{\pi}{n} \cdot \frac{(n-1)(n+1)}{8}} = e^{i \frac{(n^2-1)\pi}{8n}}
     \]

   - For even \( n \):
     \[
     a_n = \prod_{k=1}^{\frac{n-2}{2}} e^{i \frac{k\pi}{n}} = e^{i \sum_{k=1}^{\frac{n-2}{2}} \frac{k\pi}{n}} = e^{i \frac{\pi}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{\frac{n-2}{2}} k}
     \]
     The sum of the first \( \frac{n-2}{2} \) integers is:
     \[
     \sum_{k=1}^{\frac{n-2}{2}} k = \frac{\left( \frac{n-2}{2} \right) \left( \frac{n}{2} \right)}{2} = \frac{(n-2)n}{8}
     \]
     Therefore:
     \[
     a_n = e^{i \frac{\pi}{n} \cdot \frac{(n-2)n}{8}} = e^{i \frac{(n-2)\pi}{8}}
     \]

4. **Calculate \( r = a_1 a_2 \cdots a_{10} \):**
   \[
   r = a_1 a_2 a_3 \cdots a_{10}
   \]
   Since \( a_1 = 1 \) and \( a_2 = 1 \), we only need to consider \( a_3 \) to \( a_{10} \):
   \[
   r = e^{i \left( \frac{2\pi}{3} + \frac{\pi}{2} + \frac{6\pi}{5} + \pi + \frac{12\pi}{7} + \frac{3\pi}{2} + \frac{20\pi}{9} + 2\pi \right)}
   \]
   Simplify the sum of the arguments:
   \[
   \frac{2\pi}{3} + \frac{\pi}{2} + \frac{6\pi}{5} + \pi + \frac{12\pi}{7} + \frac{3\pi}{2} + \frac{20\pi}{9} + 2\pi = \frac{3403\pi}{315}
   \]
   Therefore:
   \[
   r = e^{i \frac{3403\pi}{315}}
   \]
   Simplify the argument modulo \( 2\pi \):
   \[
   \frac{3403\pi}{315} = \frac{253\pi}{315} \pmod{2\pi}
   \]
   Thus:
   \[
   r = e^{i \frac{253\pi}{315}}
   \]

5. **Determine the smallest integer \( k \) such that \( r \) is a root of \( x^k = 1 \):**
   We need \( \frac{253\pi}{315} \) to be an integer multiple of \( \frac{2\pi}{k} \):
   \[
   \frac{253}{315} = \frac{2m}{k} \quad \text{for some integer} \quad m
   \]
   The smallest \( k \) is the least common multiple of the denominators, which is \( 315 \).

The final answer is \( \boxed{315} \).
informal_statement: Let $ a_n $ be the product of the complex roots of $ x^{2n} = 1 $ that are in the first quadrant of the complex plane. That is, roots of the form $ a + bi $ where $ a, b > 0 $. Let $ r = a_1 \cdots a_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{10} $. Find the smallest integer $ k $ such that $ r $ is a root of $ x^k = 1 $.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Complex Filter Function Metric Finset
open scoped BigOperators Topology

/- Let $ a_n $ be the product of the complex roots of $ x^{2n} = 1 $ that are in the first quadrant of the complex plane. That is, roots of the form $ a + bi $ where $ a, b > 0 $. Let $ r = a_1 \cdots a_2 \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{10} $. Find the smallest integer $ k $ such that $ r $ is a root of $ x^k = 1 $. -/
theorem number_theory_55547 {a : ℕ → ℂ}
    (ha : ∀ n, a n = ∏ᶠ x ∈ {z : ℂ | z ^ (2 * n) = 1 ∧ (z.re > 0 ∧ z.im > 0)}, x) :
    IsLeast {k | 0 < k ∧ (a 1 * ∏ i ∈ Icc 2 10, a i) ^ k = 1} 315 := by

soln_description:
The original inequality can be transformed into $\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}}+\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{y^{5}+z^{2}+x^{2}}+\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{z^{5}+x^{2}+y^{2}} \leqslant 3$.
By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and the condition $x y z \geqslant 1$, we get
$$
\left(x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)\left(y z+y^{2}+z^{2}\right) \geqslant\left[x^{2}(x y z)^{+}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right]^{2} \geqslant\left(x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\right)^{2} \text {, }
$$

which implies $\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}} \leqslant \frac{y z+y^{2}+z^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}$.
Similarly, $\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{y^{5}+z^{2}+x^{2}} \leqslant \frac{z x+z^{2}+x^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}, \frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{z^{5}+x^{2}+y^{2}} \leqslant \frac{x y+x^{2}+y^{2}}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}$.
Adding the above three inequalities and using $x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2} \geqslant x y+y z+z x$, we get
$$
\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}}+\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{y^{5}+z^{2}+x^{2}}+\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}{z^{5}+x^{2}+y^{2}} \leqslant 2+\frac{x y+y z+z x}{x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}} \leqslant 3 .
$$
informal_statement:
Example 11 (46th IMO Problem) Positive real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $xyz \geqslant 1$, prove:
$$
\frac{x^{3}-x^{2}}{x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}}+\frac{y^{5}-y^{2}}{y^{5}+z^{2}+x^{2}}+\frac{z^{5}-z^{2}}{z^{5}+x^{2}+y^{2}} \geqslant 0 .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 11 (46th IMO Problem) Positive real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $xyz \geqslant 1$, prove:
$$
\frac{x^{3}-x^{2}}{x^{5}+y^{2}+z^{2}}+\frac{y^{5}-y^{2}}{y^{5}+z^{2}+x^{2}}+\frac{z^{5}-z^{2}}{z^{5}+x^{2}+y^{2}} \geqslant 0 .
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_255825 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : 0 < x) (hy : 0 < y) (hz : 0 < z)
    (hxyz : x * y * z ≥ 1) :
    0 ≤ (x ^ 3 - x ^ 2) / (x ^ 5 + y ^ 2 + z ^ 2) +
        (y ^ 5 - y ^ 2) / (y ^ 5 + z ^ 2 + x ^ 2) +
        (z ^ 5 - z ^ 2) / (z ^ 5 + x ^ 2 + y ^ 2) := by

soln_description:
Analysis: This problem involves a non-homogeneous inequality with high degree. The key to solving this problem is to homogenize it using the given equation.

Proof: By the AM-GM inequality,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\prod(2 a+b+c) \leqslant\left[\frac{1}{4} \sum(2 a+b+c)\right]^{4} \\
=(a+b+c+d)^{4},
\end{array}
$$

Therefore, we only need to prove that $(a+b+c+d)^{4}(a b c d)^{2} \leqslant \frac{1}{16}$, which is equivalent to proving
$$
\begin{array}{l}
(a+b+c+d)^{4}(a b c d)^{2} \\
\leqslant \frac{1}{16}[(a+b)(b+c)(c+d)(d+a)]^{3} \\
\Leftrightarrow\left[( \frac { 1 } { a } + \frac { 1 } { b } ) ( \frac { 1 } { b } + \frac { 1 } { c } ) ( \frac { 1 } { c } + \frac { 1 } { d } ) \left(\frac{1}{d}+\right.\right. \\
]^{3} \\
\geqslant 16\left(\frac{1}{a b c}+\frac{1}{b c d}+\frac{1}{c d a}+\frac{1}{d a b}\right)^{4} .
\end{array}
$$
$$
\left.\left.\frac{1}{a}\right)\right]^{3}
$$

Let $\frac{1}{a}=x, \frac{1}{b}=y, \frac{1}{c}=z, \frac{1}{d}=v$, then,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Equation (1) } \Leftrightarrow[(x+y)(y+z)(z+v)(v+x)]^{3} \\
\geqslant 16(x y z+x y v+y z v+x z v)^{4} .
\end{array}
$$

Now we prove Equation (2).
$$
\begin{aligned}
& 4(x y z+x y v+y z v+x z v)^{2} \\
& =4[x y(z+v)+z v(z+y)]^{2} \\
& \leqslant 4\left[\sqrt{x y} \cdot \frac{x+y}{2}(z+v)+\sqrt{z v} \cdot \frac{z+v}{2}(x\right. \\
+y) & ]^{2} \\
& =(x+y)^{2}(z+y)^{2}(x y+z v+2 \sqrt{x y z v}) \\
& \leqslant(x+y)^{2}(z+v)^{2}(y+z)(v+x) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Similarly, $4(y z v+x z v+x y v+x y z)^{2}$
$$
\leqslant(y+z)^{2}(v+x)^{2}(x+y)(z+v) \text {. }
$$

Multiplying Equations (3) and (4) gives
$16(y z v+x z v+x y v+x y z)^{4}$
$$
\leqslant[(y+z)(v+x)(x+y)(z+v)]^{3} \text {. }
$$

Therefore, the inequality is proven.
informal_statement:
Example 7 Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive numbers, and $(a+b)(b+c)(c+d)(d+a)=1$.

Prove: $(2a+b+c)(2b+c+d)(2c+d+a)(2d+a+b)(abcd)^2 \leqslant \frac{1}{16}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Example 7 Let $a, b, c, d$ be positive numbers, and $(a+b)(b+c)(c+d)(d+a)=1$.

Prove: $(2a+b+c)(2b+c+d)(2c+d+a)(2d+a+b)(abcd)^2 \leqslant \frac{1}{16}$. -/
theorem inequalities_120340 (a b c d : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) (hd : 0 < d)
    (h : (a + b) * (b + c) * (c + d) * (d + a) = 1) :
    (2 * a + b + c) * (2 * b + c + d) * (2 * c + d + a) * (2 * d + a + b) * (a * b * c * d) ^ 2 ≤ 1 / 16 := by

informal_statement: Solve the differential equation $y^3\text{d}x + 2(x^2 - xy^2)\text{d}y = 0$ and find the general solution.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Solve the differential equation $y^3\text{d}x + 2(x^2 - xy^2)\text{d}y = 0$ and find the general solution. -/
theorem calculus_1477 (y : ℝ → ℝ) (hy : Differentiable ℝ y)
    (h : ∀ x, y x ^ 3 * deriv y x + 2 * (x ^ 2 - x * y x ^ 2) * deriv y x = 0) :
    ∃ C, ∀ x, 2 * log (y x) - y x ^ 2 / x = C := by

soln_description:
2. Let $b^{2}=c a$. The conditions of the problem give $b^{2}=c a \mid a^{4}$ and $a+1 \mid c a+1$, which is equivalent to

$$
c \mid a^{3} \quad \text { and } \quad a+1 \mid c-1 .
$$

Let $c=d(a+1)+1, d \in \mathbb{N}_{0}$. Since $a^{3} \equiv-1(\bmod (a+1))$, we have $\frac{a^{3}}{c} \equiv-1(\bmod (a+1))$, i.e., $\frac{a^{3}}{c}=e(a+1)-1$ for some $e \in \mathbb{N}$. It follows that $a^{3}=(d(a+1)+1)(e(a+1)-1)$, which after multiplication and division by $a+1$ becomes $a^{2}-a+1=d e(a+1)+(e-d)$. From here we have $e-d \equiv a^{2}-a+1 \equiv 3$ $(\bmod (a+1))$, hence

$$
e-d=k(a+1)+3 \quad \text { and } \quad d e=a-2-k \quad(k \in \mathbb{Z}) .
$$

We distinguish the following cases:

(1) $k \notin\{-1,0\}$. In this case (*) implies $d e<|e-d|-1$, which is possible only for $d=0$. Now $c=1$ and $b^{2}=a$, so $(a, b)=\left(t^{2}, t\right)$.

(2) $k=-1$. From (*) we get $a=d+1$. Now $c=a^{2}$ and $b^{2}=a^{3}$, so $(a, b)=\left(t^{2}, t^{3}\right)$.

(3) $k=0$. From (*) we get $a=d^{2}+3 d+2$. Now $c=d(a+1)+1=(d+1)^{3}$ and $b^{2}=c a=(d+1)^{4}(d+2)$. It follows that $d+2=t^{2}$ for some $t \in \mathbb{N}$, which gives $(a, b)=\left(t^{2}\left(t^{2}-1\right), t\left(t^{2}-1\right)^{2}\right), t \geq 2$.

Answer: These are pairs $(a, b)$ of the form $\left(t^{2}, t\right),\left(t^{2}, t^{3}\right)$ and $\left(t^{2}\left(t^{2}-1\right), t\left(t^{2}-1\right)^{2}\right)$, where $t \in \mathbb{N}$.
informal_statement:
2. Find all natural numbers $a$ and $b$ such that

$$
a\left|b^{2}, \quad b\right| a^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad a+1 \mid b^{2}+1 . \quad \text { (Dušan Đukić) }
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 2. Find all natural numbers $a$ and $b$ such that

$$
a\left|b^{2}, \quad b\right| a^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad a+1 \mid b^{2}+1 . \quad \text { (Dušan Đukić) }
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_107181 (a b : ℕ) :
    a ∣ b^2 ∧ b ∣ a^2 ∧ (a + 1) ∣ b^2 + 1 ↔
    (a, b) = (2, 2) ∨ (a, b) = (2, 3) ∨ (a, b) = (2^2, 2^2 - 1) ∨ (a, b) = (2^2 - 1, 2^2 - 1)^2 := by

soln_description:
# Solution

Let's take Vasya's step as 1, then Petya's step is 0.75. For every 100 steps Vasya takes, Petya takes 125 steps. After 100 steps, Vasya will have walked a distance of 100, while Petya will have walked $0.75 * 125 = 75$ in the same time. Therefore, Vasya will arrive faster.

## Grading Criteria

Correct answer obtained without justification - 1 point.

Correct answer obtained with justification - 7 points.
informal_statement: 1. Two boys, Petya and Vasya, are walking from the same house to the same school at the same time. Petya's step is $25\%$ shorter than Vasya's, but in the same amount of time, he manages to take $25\%$ more steps than Vasya. Who will arrive at the school first?
informal_proof:
To determine who arrives at the school first, we must compare their travel times. Let `v` be Vasya's speed, `p` be Petya's speed, and `d` be the distance to the school. We are given that `d`, `p`, and `v` are all positive quantities. The time taken for Vasya is `t_v = d/v` and for Petya is `t_p = d/p`. We will show that `d/v < d/p`, which means Vasya's time is less than Petya's.

The argument is based on the relationships between `d`, `p`, and `v` provided. Specifically, we are given that `p = (1 - 25/100) * v`.

First, we establish a direct comparison between `p` and `v`. The given relation simplifies to `p = 0.75 * v`. Since `v` is a positive number and `0.75` is strictly less than `1`, it follows that `p` must be strictly less than `v`.

To prove the desired inequality `d/v < d/p`, we will prove the equivalent inequality `d/v - d/p < 0`. We begin by expressing the left-hand side as a single fraction by finding a common denominator:
$$ \frac{d}{v} - \frac{d}{p} = \frac{d \cdot p - d \cdot v}{v \cdot p} = \frac{d \cdot (p - v)}{v \cdot p} $$
Now, we determine the sign of this fraction by analyzing its numerator and denominator.

1.  **Denominator:** The denominator is `v \cdot p`. We are given that `v > 0` and `p > 0`. The product of two positive numbers is positive, so `v \cdot p > 0`.

2.  **Numerator:** The numerator is `d \cdot (p - v)`. From our earlier deduction that `p < v`, it follows that the difference `p - v` is a negative number. We are given that `d` is positive. The product of a positive number (`d`) and a negative number (`p - v`) is negative. Thus, the numerator `d \cdot (p - v)` is negative.

Since the numerator `d \cdot (p - v)` is negative and the denominator `v \cdot p` is positive, their quotient must be negative. Therefore, we have:
$$ \frac{d \cdot (p - v)}{v \cdot p} < 0 $$
This implies that `d/v - d/p < 0`. By adding `d/p` to both sides of this inequality, we arrive at the final result:
$$ \frac{d}{v} < \frac{d}{p} $$
This inequality shows that Vasya's travel time (`d/v`) is less than Petya's travel time (`d/p`). Therefore, Vasya will arrive at the school first.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Two boys, Petya and Vasya, are walking from the same house to the same school at the same time. Petya's step is $25\%$ shorter than Vasya's, but in the same amount of time, he manages to take $25\%$ more steps than Vasya. Who will arrive at the school first? -/
theorem algebra_108940 (d p v : ℝ) (h₀ : d > 0) (h₁ : p > 0) (h₂ : v > 0)
    (h₃ : p = (1 - 25 / 100) * v) (h₄ : p * (1 + 25 / 100) = d) :
    d / v < d / p := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_108940 (d p v : ℝ) (h₀ : d > 0) (h₁ : p > 0) (h₂ : v > 0)
    (h₃ : p = (1 - 25 / 100) * v) (h₄ : p * (1 + 25 / 100) = d) :
    d / v < d / p := by
  have h7 : p < v := by
    nlinarith [h₃, h₂]
  have pos1 : v * p > 0 := by
    apply mul_pos
    all_goals linarith
  have pos2 : d * (p - v) < 0 := by
    have : p - v < 0 := by linarith
    have hd : d > 0 := h₀
    nlinarith
  have h8 : d / v - d / p < 0 := by
    have h9 : d / v - d / p = (d * (p - v)) / (v * p) := by
      field_simp
      <;> ring
    rw [h9]
    apply div_neg_of_neg_of_pos
    linarith
    positivity
  linarith

soln_description:
Let $x=\frac{2 a^{2}}{b c}, y=\frac{2 b^{2}}{a c}, z=\frac{2 c^{2}}{a b}$. Then $x y z=8$.
Therefore, the original expression can be transformed as
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\frac{1}{x+1}+\frac{1}{y+1}+\frac{1}{z+1}=1 \\
\Rightarrow x y z=x+y+z+2 \\
\Rightarrow x+y+z=6 .
\end{array}
$$

Substituting $a, b, c$ into the expanded form, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
a^{3}+b^{3}+c^{3}=3 a b c . \\
\text { Hence }(a+b+c)\left[(a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2}\right]=0 \text {. }
\end{array}
$$

Since $a, b, c$ are not all equal, we have
$$
(a-b)^{2}+(b-c)^{2}+(c-a)^{2} \neq 0 \text {. }
$$

Therefore, $a+b+c=0$.
informal_statement:
5. Let non-zero real numbers $a, b, c$ be not all equal and satisfy
$$
\frac{b c}{2 a^{2}+b c}+\frac{a c}{2 b^{2}+a c}+\frac{a b}{2 c^{2}+a b}=1 \text {. }
$$

Find the value of $a+b+c$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 5. Let non-zero real numbers $a, b, c$ be not all equal and satisfy
$$
\frac{b c}{2 a^{2}+b c}+\frac{a c}{2 b^{2}+a c}+\frac{a b}{2 c^{2}+a b}=1 \text {. }
$$

Find the value of $a+b+c$. -/
theorem algebra_299807 {a b c : ℝ} (ha : a ≠ 0) (hb : b ≠ 0) (hc : c ≠ 0)
    (hne : ¬(a = b ∧ b = c)) (h : b * c / (2 * a ^ 2 + b * c) + a * c / (2 * b ^ 2 + a * c) +
      a * b / (2 * c ^ 2 + a * b) = 1) : a + b + c = 0 := by

soln_description:
Let the members of the given geometric progression be: $a, a q, a q^{2} \ldots a q^{n}$. We form a sequence of logarithms of consecutive members of the given geometric progression to some base $k$, where $k>0, k \neq 1$:

$$
\log _{k} a, \log _{k} a+\log _{k} q, \log _{k} a+2 \log _{k} q, \ldots, \log _{k} a+n \log _{k} q
$$

The resulting sequence forms an arithmetic progression with the common difference of the progression equal to $\log _{k} q$.
informal_statement: 410. Prove that the logarithms of consecutive terms of a geometric progression form an arithmetic progression with the difference of the progression equal to the logarithm of the common ratio of the given geometric progression.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 410. Prove that the logarithms of consecutive terms of a geometric progression form an arithmetic progression with the difference of the progression equal to the logarithm of the common ratio of the given geometric progression. -/
theorem algebra_278169 {a r : ℝ} (hr : r > 0) (h : ∀ n, a * r ^ n > 0) :
    ∃ d, ∀ n, log (a * r ^ n) = log a + d * n := by

soln_description:
4.A.

Since $a=\frac{1}{2} \cos 6^{\circ}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \sin 6^{\circ}=\sin 24^{\circ}$,
$$
\begin{aligned}
b & =\frac{2 \tan 13^{\circ}}{1-\tan ^{2} 13^{\circ}}=\tan 26^{\circ}, \\
c & =\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos 50^{\circ}}{2}}=\sin 25^{\circ},
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $a<c$.
Also, for $x \in\left(0, \frac{\pi}{2}\right)$, we have $\sin x<x<\tan x$. Hence $\sin 25^{\circ}<\sin 26^{\circ}<\tan 26^{\circ}$, which means $c<b$.

$$
b=\frac{2 \tan 13^{\circ}}{1-\tan ^{2} 13^{\circ}}, c=\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos 50^{\circ}}{2}} \text {. }

Then we have ().

  (ha : a = (1/2) * cos (6 * π/180) - (Real.sqrt 3/2) * sin (6 * π/180))

soln_description:
Assume that a real number $ c $ has the considered property:

Substituting $ y=tx $ and dividing both sides by $ x^{a+1} $, we obtain the relation

Notice that the converse is also true: condition (2) implies (1). Suppose that $ c $ is a real number satisfying condition (2). Let $ x $, $ y $ be any positive numbers. In inequality (2), substitute $ t = y/x $, multiply both sides by $ x^{a+1} $, and we get inequality (1).
Therefore, conditions (1) and (2) are equivalent. Fix a real number $ c $ and consider the function $ f:(0,\ \infty)\to \mathbb{R} $ given by

of course $ f(1) = c - 1 $ and

If condition (2) (equivalent to condition (1)) is satisfied for the considered number $ c $, then the function $ f $ has a minimum at the point $ t = 1 $, so $ f'(1) = 0 $, which means $ c(a+1)-a= 0 $; hence $ c=\frac{a}{a+1} $.
Conversely, if in the definition of the function $ f $ we take $ c= \frac{a}{a+1} $, then

therefore, the function $ f $ is decreasing in the interval $ (0;\ 1 \rangle $ and increasing in the interval $ \langle 1;\ \infty) $. At the point $ t = 1 $, it therefore attains its minimum value. In other words, $ f(t)\geq f(1) $ for $ t>0 $, which means that condition (2) (equivalent to condition (1)) is satisfied.
Conclusion: for a given positive number $ a $, the only number $ c $ having the postulated property is $ c=\frac{a}{a+1} $.
informal_statement:
XLIX OM - I - Problem 4

Given a positive number $ a $. Determine all real numbers $ c $ that have the following property: for every pair of positive numbers $ x $, $ y $, the inequality $ (c-1)x^{a+1}  \leq (cy - x)y^a $ is satisfied.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- XLIX OM - I - Problem 4

Given a positive number $ a $. Determine all real numbers $ c $ that have the following property: for every pair of positive numbers $ x $, $ y $, the inequality $ (c-1)x^{a+1}  \leq (cy - x)y^a $ is satisfied. -/
theorem inequalities_125969 (a : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (c : ℝ) :
    (∀ x y : ℝ, 0 < x → 0 < y → (c - 1) * x^(a + 1) ≤ (c * y - x) * y^a) ↔
    c = a / (a + 1) := by

soln_description:
【Answer】Solution: The repeating decimal $0.01^{4285} 7$ has a cycle of 6 digits, the first digit of the decimal part is 0, and the 2014th digit after the decimal point is $2014 \div 6=335$ (groups) $\cdots 4$,

The remainder is 4, so the 4th digit in the 336th cycle is 8,
Thus, the sum of the first 2015 digits of the decimal part is:
$$
\begin{aligned}
& (1+4+2+8+5+7) \times 335+1+4+2+8 \\
= & 27 \times 335+15 \\
= & 9045+15 \\
= & 9060 ;
\end{aligned}
$$

Answer: The sum is 9060.
Therefore, the answer is: 9060.
informal_statement:
9. (6 points) The sum of the first 2015 digits in the decimal part of the repeating decimal 0.0142857 . is $\qquad$

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 9. (6 points) The sum of the first 2015 digits in the decimal part of the repeating decimal 0.0142857 . is $\qquad$

Translate the above text into English, please retain the original text's line breaks and format, and output the translation result directly. -/
theorem number_theory_208777 : (Nat.floor ((10 ^ 2014) * (60 / 99 : ℝ)) % 10000 = 9060) := by

informal_statement: 52. Let positive real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $x+y+z=x y z$, find the minimum value of $x^{7}(y z-1)+y^{7}(z x-1)+$ $z^{7}(x y-1)$. (2003 China National Training Team Problem)

/- 52. Let positive real numbers $x, y, z$ satisfy $x+y+z=x y z$, find the minimum value of $x^{7}(y z-1)+y^{7}(z x-1)+$ $z^{7}(x y-1)$. (2003 China National Training Team Problem) -/
theorem algebra_603407 :
    IsLeast {t : ℝ | ∃ x y z : ℝ, x > 0 ∧ y > 0 ∧ z > 0 ∧ x + y + z = x * y * z ∧ t = x^7 * (y * z - 1) + y^7 * (z * x - 1) + z^7 * (x * y - 1)} (162 * sqrt 3) := by

soln_description:
(1) Let $x_{1}=1=\sin \frac{\pi}{2}, y_{1}=0=\cos \frac{\pi}{2}$, then $x_{2}=x_{1} \sqrt{\frac{1}{2\left(\sqrt{1-x_{1}^{2}}+1\right)}}=\sin \frac{\pi}{4}$, $y_{2}=\cos \frac{\pi}{4}$.
By mathematical induction, we can prove that
$$
x_{n}=\sin \frac{\pi}{2^{n}}, y_{n}=\cos \frac{\pi}{2^{n}} \text {. }
$$

Thus, $x_{n} x_{n+1}+y_{n} y_{n+1}$
$$
=\cos \left(\frac{\pi}{2^{n}}-\frac{\pi}{2^{n+1}}\right)=y_{n+1} \text {. }
$$
(2) $a_{n}=x_{n}+y_{n}=\sin \frac{\pi}{2^{n}}+\cos \frac{\pi}{2^{n}}$
$$
=\sqrt{2} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{2^{n}}+\frac{\pi}{4}\right) \leqslant \sqrt{2} \text {. }
$$
informal_statement:
9. (16 points) Given the sequences $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{y_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}=1, x_{n+1}=x_{n} \sqrt{\frac{1}{2\left(\sqrt{1-x_{n}^{2}}+1\right)}}, \\
y_{1}=0, y_{n+1}=\sqrt{\frac{y_{n}+1}{2}} .
\end{array}
$$

Prove: (1) $x_{n} x_{n+1}+y_{n} y_{n+1}=y_{n+1}$;
(2) If $a_{n}=x_{n}+y_{n}$, then
$$
a_{n} \leqslant \sqrt{2} \quad (n=1,2, \cdots) .
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 9. (16 points) Given the sequences $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{y_{n}\right\}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x_{1}=1, x_{n+1}=x_{n} \sqrt{\frac{1}{2\left(\sqrt{1-x_{n}^{2}}+1\right)}}, \\
y_{1}=0, y_{n+1}=\sqrt{\frac{y_{n}+1}{2}} .
\end{array}
$$

Prove: (1) $x_{n} x_{n+1}+y_{n} y_{n+1}=y_{n+1}$;
(2) If $a_{n}=x_{n}+y_{n}$, then
$$
a_{n} \leqslant \sqrt{2} \quad (n=1,2, \cdots) .
$$ -/
theorem algebra_322402 {x y : ℕ → ℝ}
    (hx1 : x 1 = 1)
    (hxn : ∀ n, x (n + 1) = x n * sqrt (1 / (2 * (sqrt (1 - (x n)^2) + 1))))
    (hy1 : y 1 = 0)
    (hy : ∀ n, y (n + 1) = sqrt ((y n + 1) / 2)) :
    (∀ n, x n * x (n + 1) + y n * y (n + 1) = y (n + 1)) ∧
    (∀ n, x n + y n ≤ sqrt 2) := by

soln_description:
Proof: By the homogeneity of equation (1), we can set $x_{1 j}+x_{2 j}+\cdots+x_{m j}=1$, where $j \in\{1,2, \cdots, n\}$. Then we only need to prove

that is $\square$
$$\begin{array}{c}
\prod_{j=1}^{n} 1^{\omega_{j}} \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{m} \prod_{j=1}^{n} x_{i j}^{\omega_{j}} \\
1 \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{m} \prod_{j=1}^{n} x_{i j}^{\omega_{j}}
\end{array}$$

By the weighted arithmetic mean-geometric mean inequality, we have
$$\sum_{j=1}^{n} \omega_{j} x_{i j} \geqslant \prod_{j=1}^{n} x_{i j}^{\omega_{j}}(i \in\{1,2, \cdots, m\})$$

Therefore,
$$\sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \omega_{j} x_{i j} \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{m} \prod_{j=1}^{n} x_{i j}^{\omega_{j}}$$

In fact, we have
$$\sum_{i=1}^{m} \sum_{j=1}^{n} \omega_{j} x_{i j}=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{m} \omega_{j} x_{i j}=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \omega_{j}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{i j}\right)=\sum_{j=1}^{n} \omega_{j}=1$$

Thus, equation (2) holds, which means equation (1) holds.
informal_statement:
Example 1 Let $x_{ij} (i=1,2, \cdots, m, j=1,2, \cdots n)$ be positive real numbers, and positive real numbers $\omega_{1}$, $\omega_{2}, \cdots, \omega_{n}$ satisfy $\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}+\cdots+\omega_{n}=1$, prove
$$\prod_{j=1}^{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{ij}\right)^{w_{j}} \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{m}\left(\prod_{j=1}^{n} x_{ij}^{\omega_{j}}\right)$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 1 Let $x_{ij} (i=1,2, \cdots, m, j=1,2, \cdots n)$ be positive real numbers, and positive real numbers $\omega_{1}$, $\omega_{2}, \cdots, \omega_{n}$ satisfy $\omega_{1}+\omega_{2}+\cdots+\omega_{n}=1$, prove
$$\prod_{j=1}^{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m} x_{ij}\right)^{w_{j}} \geqslant \sum_{i=1}^{m}\left(\prod_{j=1}^{n} x_{ij}^{\omega_{j}}\right)$$ -/
theorem inequalities_600339 {m n : ℕ} (x : Fin m → Fin n → ℝ)
    (hx : ∀ i j, 0 < x i j) (ω : Fin n → ℝ)
    (hω : ∑ j, ω j = 1) (hω' : ∀ i, 0 < ω i) :
    ∏ j, (∑ i, x i j) ^ (ω j) ≥
    ∑ i, (∏ j, (x i j) ^ (ω j)) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Let $t$ be the time (in minutes) it takes for the second particle to catch up with the first. The distance traveled by the second particle is equal to the sum of $t$ terms of an arithmetic progression with $a_{1}=3, d=0.5$; therefore, $s=\frac{2 a_{1}+d(t-1)}{2} t=\frac{6+0.5(t-1)}{2} t$. The same distance traveled by the first particle is $5(6.8+t)=34+5 t$. Thus, $\frac{6+0.5(t-1)}{2} t=34+5 t$, from which $t=17$ (min).

Answer: 17 min.
informal_statement: 13.113. A material particle entered the pipe through an opening, and 6.8 minutes later, a second particle entered the same opening. Upon entering the pipe, each particle immediately began linear motion along the pipe: the first particle moved uniformly at a speed of 5 m/min, while the second particle covered 3 m in the first minute and 0.5 m more in each subsequent minute than in the previous one. How many minutes will it take for the second particle to catch up with the first?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 13.113. A material particle entered the pipe through an opening, and 6.8 minutes later, a second particle entered the same opening. Upon entering the pipe, each particle immediately began linear motion along the pipe: the first particle moved uniformly at a speed of 5 m/min, while the second particle covered 3 m in the first minute and 0.5 m more in each subsequent minute than in the previous one. How many minutes will it take for the second particle to catch up with the first? -/
theorem algebra_194051 (t : ℝ) (ht : t > 0) (h : 5 * t = 3 * (t - 6.8) + 0.5 * (t - 6.8)^2) :
    t = 17 := by

soln_description:
1. Given that \(a\) is a perfect square, we can write \(a = k^2\) for some integer \(k\). Also, \(a = pq\) where \(p\) and \(q\) are positive integers.
2. We need to prove that \(2021\) divides \(\sqrt{a}\). Since \(a = k^2\), we need to show that \(2021\) divides \(k\).
3. We are given that \(2021 \mid p^3 + q^3 + p^2q + pq^2\). We can factorize the expression as follows:
   \[
   p^3 + q^3 + p^2q + pq^2 = (p+q)(p^2 - pq + q^2 + pq) = (p+q)(p^2 + q^2 + pq)
   \]
4. Since \(2021 = 43 \times 47\), we need to show that both \(43\) and \(47\) divide \(k\).
5. Assume \(p = x^2z\) and \(q = y^2z\) for some integers \(x, y, z\). Then, \(a = pq = (x^2z)(y^2z) = x^2y^2z^2\), so \(\sqrt{a} = xyz\).
6. Substituting \(p = x^2z\) and \(q = y^2z\) into the expression, we get:
   \[
   p^3 + q^3 + p^2q + pq^2 = (x^2z)^3 + (y^2z)^3 + (x^2z)^2(y^2z) + (x^2z)(y^2z)^2
   \]
   Simplifying, we have:
   \[
   p^3 + q^3 + p^2q + pq^2 = x^6z^3 + y^6z^3 + x^4y^2z^3 + x^2y^4z^3 = z^3(x^6 + y^6 + x^4y^2 + x^2y^4)
   \]
7. Since \(2021 \mid z^3(x^6 + y^6 + x^4y^2 + x^2y^4)\), it follows that \(43 \mid z^3(x^6 + y^6 + x^4y^2 + x^2y^4)\) and \(47 \mid z^3(x^6 + y^6 + x^4y^2 + x^2y^4)\).
8. Consider the prime factor \(43\). If \(43 \mid z\), then \(43 \mid xyz = \sqrt{a}\). If \(43 \nmid z\), then \(43\) must divide \(x^6 + y^6 + x^4y^2 + x^2y^4\). Since \(43 \equiv 3 \pmod{4}\), by Fermat's theorem on sums of two squares, \(x^2 + y^2 \equiv 0 \pmod{43}\) implies \(43 \mid x\) and \(43 \mid y\). Thus, \(43 \mid xyz = \sqrt{a}\).
9. Similarly, consider the prime factor \(47\). If \(47 \mid z\), then \(47 \mid xyz = \sqrt{a}\). If \(47 \nmid z\), then \(47\) must divide \(x^6 + y^6 + x^4y^2 + x^2y^4\). Since \(47 \equiv 3 \pmod{4}\), by Fermat's theorem on sums of two squares, \(x^2 + y^2 \equiv 0 \pmod{47}\) implies \(47 \mid x\) and \(47 \mid y\). Thus, \(47 \mid xyz = \sqrt{a}\).
10. Since both \(43\) and \(47\) divide \(\sqrt{a}\), it follows that \(2021 = 43 \times 47\) divides \(\sqrt{a}\).

\(\blacksquare\)
informal_statement:
Let $a,p,q\in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge 1}$ be such that $a$ is a perfect square, $a=pq$ and
$$2021~|~p^3+q^3+p^2q+pq^2.$$
Prove that $2021$ divides $\sqrt a$.\\ \\ 
[i](Cosmin Gavrilă)[/i]
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $a,p,q\in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge 1}$ be such that $a$ is a perfect square, $a=pq$ and
$$2021~|~p^3+q^3+p^2q+pq^2.$$
Prove that $2021$ divides $\sqrt a$.\\ \\ 
[i](Cosmin Gavrilă)[/i] -/
theorem number_theory_34994 (a p q : ℕ) (ha : 1 ≤ a) (hp : 1 ≤ p) (hq : 1 ≤ q)
    (h : ∃ m, m^2 = a) (h1 : a = p * q) (h2 : 2021 ∣ p^3 + q^3 + p^2 * q + p * q^2) :
    2021 ∣ Nat.sqrt a := by

soln_description:
[Solution] From the property of $f(x)$, we get
$$f(x)=x^{2}-f(x-1) .$$

Repeatedly applying the above formula, we obtain
$$\begin{aligned}
f(94) & =94^{2}-f(93) \\
& =94^{2}-93^{2}+f(92) \\
& =94^{2}-93^{2}+92^{2}-f(91) \\
& \cdots \\
& =94^{2}-93^{2}+92^{2}-91^{2}+\cdots+20^{2}-f(19) \\
& =187+183+\cdots+43+400-94 \\
& =\frac{187+43}{2} \cdot\left(\frac{187-43}{4}+1\right)+400-94 \\
& =4561 .
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the remainder when $f(94)$ is divided by 1000 is 561.
informal_statement:
6.29 For any real number $x$, the function $f(x)$ has the property
$$f(x)+f(x-1)=x^{2}$$

If $f(19)=94$, then what is the remainder when $f(94)$ is divided by 1000?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 6.29 For any real number $x$, the function $f(x)$ has the property
$$f(x)+f(x-1)=x^{2}$$

If $f(19)=94$, then what is the remainder when $f(94)$ is divided by 1000? -/
theorem algebra_597427 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (h : ∀ x, f x + f (x - 1) = x ^ 2) (h' : f 19 = 94) :
    (f 94) % 1000 = 561 := by

informal_statement:
Given the function $f\left( x \right)=a{{x}^{2}}-c$ satisfies: $-4 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 1 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } -1$, $-1 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 2 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 5$, then $f\left( 3 \right)$ should satisfy (    ):

A: $7 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 26$

B: $-4 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 15$

C: $-1 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 20$

D: $-\frac{28}{3} \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } \frac{35}{3}$
informal_proof:
We are given a function $f(x) = ax^2 - c$ for some real numbers $a$ and $c$. We are also given the following bounds:
1.  $-4 \le f(1) \le -1$
2.  $-1 \le f(2) \le 5$

Our goal is to prove that $-1 \le f(3) \le 20$.

First, let's evaluate the function $f$ at the points $x=1$, $x=2$, and $x=3$ using its definition:
-   $f(1) = a(1)^2 - c = a - c$
-   $f(2) = a(2)^2 - c = 4a - c$
-   $f(3) = a(3)^2 - c = 9a - c$

Now, we can translate the given bounds on $f(1)$ and $f(2)$ into inequalities involving $a$ and $c$.
From the bounds on $f(1)$, we have:
$$-4 \le a - c \le -1$$
This gives us two inequalities:
(i) $-4 \le a - c$
(ii) $a - c \le -1$

From the bounds on $f(2)$, we have:
$$-1 \le 4a - c \le 5$$
This gives us two more inequalities:
(iii) $-1 \le 4a - c$
(iv) $4a - c \le 5$

We need to prove that $-1 \le f(3) \le 20$, which is equivalent to proving $-1 \le 9a - c$ and $9a - c \le 20$. We will prove these two statements separately.

**Part 1: Proving $-1 \le f(3)$**
We want to show that $-1 \le 9a - c$. We can express $9a-c$ as a linear combination of the terms $a-c$ and $4a-c$. Let's try to find coefficients $k_1$ and $k_2$ such that $9a-c = k_1(4a-c) + k_2(a-c)$. A suitable choice is $k_1 = \frac{8}{3}$ and $k_2 = -\frac{5}{3}$, since $\frac{8}{3}(4a-c) - \frac{5}{3}(a-c) = \frac{32a - 8c - 5a + 5c}{3} = \frac{27a - 3c}{3} = 9a - c$.

Using inequality (iii), we have $-1 \le 4a - c$. Multiplying by $\frac{8}{3}$ (a positive number), we get:
$$-\frac{8}{3} \le \frac{8}{3}(4a - c)$$
Using inequality (ii), we have $a - c \le -1$. Multiplying by $-\frac{5}{3}$ (a negative number) reverses the inequality:
$$-\frac{5}{3}(a - c) \ge -\frac{5}{3}(-1) \implies \frac{5}{3} \le -\frac{5}{3}(a - c)$$
Adding these two resulting inequalities gives the lower bound for $f(3)$:
$$-\frac{8}{3} + \frac{5}{3} \le \frac{8}{3}(4a - c) - \frac{5}{3}(a - c)$$
$$-1 \le 9a - c$$
Thus, we have shown that $-1 \le f(3)$.

**Part 2: Proving $f(3) \le 20$**
Next, we show that $9a - c \le 20$. We use the same linear combination as before.
Using inequality (iv), we have $4a - c \le 5$. Multiplying by $\frac{8}{3}$ gives:
$$\frac{8}{3}(4a - c) \le \frac{40}{3}$$
Using inequality (i), we have $-4 \le a - c$. Multiplying by $-\frac{5}{3}$ reverses the inequality:
$$-\frac{5}{3}(a - c) \le -\frac{5}{3}(-4) \implies -\frac{5}{3}(a - c) \le \frac{20}{3}$$
Adding these two inequalities gives the upper bound for $f(3)$:
$$\frac{8}{3}(4a - c) - \frac{5}{3}(a - c) \le \frac{40}{3} + \frac{20}{3}$$
$$9a - c \le \frac{60}{3}$$
$$9a - c \le 20$$
Thus, we have shown that $f(3) \le 20$.

Since we have proved both $-1 \le f(3)$ and $f(3) \le 20$, we can conclude that $-1 \le f(3) \le 20$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Given the function $f\left( x \right)=a{{x}^{2}}-c$ satisfies: $-4 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 1 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } -1$, $-1 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 2 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 5$, then $f\left( 3 \right)$ should satisfy (    ):

A: $7 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 26$

B: $-4 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 15$

C: $-1 \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } 20$

D: $-\frac{28}{3} \mathsf{\leqslant } f\left( 3 \right) \mathsf{\leqslant } \frac{35}{3}$ -/
theorem algebra_10473 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (a c : ℝ) (hf : ∀ x, f x = a * x ^ 2 - c)
    (h1 : -4 ≤ f 1 ∧ f 1 ≤ -1) (h2 : -1 ≤ f 2 ∧ f 2 ≤ 5) :
    -1 ≤ f 3 ∧ f 3 ≤ 20 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_10473 (f : ℝ → ℝ) (a c : ℝ) (hf : ∀ x, f x = a * x ^ 2 - c)
    (h1 : -4 ≤ f 1 ∧ f 1 ≤ -1) (h2 : -1 ≤ f 2 ∧ f 2 ≤ 5) :
    -1 ≤ f 3 ∧ f 3 ≤ 20 := by
  have eq1 : f 1 = a - c := by
    rw [hf 1]
    ring
  have eq2 : f 2 = 4 * a - c := by
    rw [hf 2]
    ring
  have eq3 : f 3 = 9 * a - c := by
    rw [hf 3]
    ring
  have h11 : -4 ≤ a - c := by 
    linarith [h1.1, eq1]
  have h12 : a - c ≤ -1 := by 
    linarith [h1.2, eq1]
  have h21 : -1 ≤ 4 * a - c := by 
    linarith [h2.1, eq2]
  have h22 : 4 * a - c ≤ 5 := by 
    linarith [h2.2, eq2]
  constructor
  · -- Proof that -1 ≤ f 3
    linarith [eq3, h11, h12, h21, h22]
  · -- Proof that f 3 ≤ 20
    linarith [eq3, h11, h12, h21, h22]

soln_description: Let the digits of n be a d , a d-1 , ... , a 0 , so that n = a d 10 d + ... + a 0 . Then n(k) = a d 10 d-k + a d-1 10 d-k-1 + ... + a k . Obviously s = a d + ... + a 0 . Hence s + 9 n(1) + ... + 9 n(d) = a d (9.10 d-1 + 9.10 d-2 + ... + 9 + 1) + a d-1 (9.10 d-2 + ... + 9 + 1) + ... + a d-k (9.10 d-k-1 + ... + 9 + 1) + a 1 (9 + 1) + a 0 = a d 10 d + ... + a 0 = n. 13th APMO 2001 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 11 Apr 2002
informal_statement: 13th APMO 2001 Problem 1 If n is a positive integer, let d+1 be the number of digits in n (in base 10) and s be the sum of the digits. Let n(k) be the number formed by deleting the last k digits of n. Prove that n = s + 9 n(1) + 9 n(2) + ... + 9 n(d).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

def d : ℕ → ℕ
| n => (Nat.digits 10 n).length

def s : ℕ → ℕ
| n => (Nat.digits 10 n).sum

def n' : ℕ → ℕ → ℕ
| n, k => n / 10 ^ k % 10 ^ (d n - k)

/- 13th APMO 2001 Problem 1 If n is a positive integer, let d+1 be the number of digits in n (in base 10) and s be the sum of the digits. Let n(k) be the number formed by deleting the last k digits of n. Prove that n = s + 9 n(1) + 9 n(2) + ... + 9 n(d). -/
theorem number_theory_128595 (n : ℕ) (hn : 0 < n) :
    n = s n + ∑ i ∈ Finset.range (d n), 9 * n' n i := by

informal_statement: Prove that every positive integer $n$ can be expressed as a sum of one or more numbers of the form $2^r 3^s$, where $r$ and $s$ are non-negative integers, and no summand divides another.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open BigOperators

/- Prove that every positive integer $n$ can be expressed as a sum of one or more numbers of the form $2^r 3^s$, where $r$ and $s$ are non-negative integers, and no summand divides another. -/
theorem number_theory_4286 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) :
    ∃ t : Finset ℕ,
      n = ∑ i ∈ t, i ∧
      (∀ i ∈ t, ∃ r s : ℕ, i = 2 ^ r * 3 ^ s) ∧
      ∀ i ∈ t, ∀ j ∈ t, i ≠ j → ¬ i ∣ j := by

soln_description:
Proof: Since $ab + bc + ca = 1$, we have:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\frac{b^{2} + c^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2} + 1}} = \frac{b^{2} + c^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2} + ab + bc + ca}} \\
= \frac{2(b^{2} + c^{2})}{2 \sqrt{(a + b)(a + c)}}
\end{array}$$

Since $\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{(a+b) + (a+c)} = \frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2a + b + c}$, we get:
$$\begin{array}{l}
= \left[\frac{(b+c)^{2}}{2a + b + c} + \frac{2a + b + c}{4}\right] - \frac{a}{2} - \frac{b}{4} - \frac{c}{4} \\
\geq (b + c) - \frac{a}{2} - \frac{b}{4} - \frac{c}{4} = \frac{3b}{4} + \frac{3c}{4} - \frac{a}{2}.
\end{array}$$

Thus, the left side of equation (1):
$$\begin{array}{l}
= \sum \frac{b^{2} + c^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2} + 1}} \geq \sum \left(\frac{3b}{4} + \frac{3c}{4} - \frac{a}{2}\right) \\
= \frac{3}{4} \sum b + \frac{3}{4} \sum c - \frac{1}{2} \sum a \\
= \frac{3}{4} \sum a + \frac{3}{4} \sum a - \frac{1}{2} \sum a \\
= \sum a = \sqrt{(a + b + c)^{2}} \\
\geq \sqrt{3(ab + bc + ca)} = \sqrt{3}.
\end{array}$$

Therefore, the original inequality is proved.
informal_statement:
Example 1 Let $a, b, c > 0$, and $ab + bc + ca = 1$.
Prove: $\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2}+1}}+\frac{c^{2}+a^{2}}{\sqrt{b^{2}+1}}+\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{\sqrt{c^{2}+1}} \geqslant \sqrt{3}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 1 Let $a, b, c > 0$, and $ab + bc + ca = 1$.
Prove: $\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}}{\sqrt{a^{2}+1}}+\frac{c^{2}+a^{2}}{\sqrt{b^{2}+1}}+\frac{a^{2}+b^{2}}{\sqrt{c^{2}+1}} \geqslant \sqrt{3}$. -/
theorem inequalities_597671 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c)
    (h : a * b + b * c + c * a = 1) :
    sqrt 3 ≤ (b ^ 2 + c ^ 2) / sqrt (a ^ 2 + 1) +
            (c ^ 2 + a ^ 2) / sqrt (b ^ 2 + 1) +
            (a ^ 2 + b ^ 2) / sqrt (c ^ 2 + 1) := by

soln_description:
## Solution.

Let $a$ be the length of the side opposite to angle $\alpha$, $b$ be the length of the side opposite to angle $\beta$, and $c$ be the length of the side opposite to angle $\gamma$ of the given triangle.

By applying the Law of Sines, we have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{a}{\sin \alpha} & =2 R \Longrightarrow \sin \alpha=\frac{a}{2 R} \\
\frac{b}{\sin \beta} & =2 R \Longrightarrow \sin \beta=\frac{b}{2 R} \\
\frac{c}{\sin \gamma} & =2 R \Longrightarrow \sin \gamma=\frac{c}{2 R}
\end{aligned}
$$

Substituting the expressions for the sines into the given equation, we get

$$
\frac{\frac{c^{2}}{4 R^{2}}+\frac{b^{2}}{4 R^{2}}-\frac{a^{2}}{4 R^{2}}}{\frac{b}{2 R} \cdot \frac{c}{2 R}}=\sqrt{3}
$$

which simplifies to

$$
\frac{c^{2}+b^{2}-a^{2}}{b c}=\sqrt{3}
$$

or $c^{2}+b^{2}-a^{2}=\sqrt{3} b c$.

According to the Law of Cosines, $\cos \alpha=\frac{b^{2}+c^{2}-a^{2}}{2 b c}$, so

$$
\cos \alpha=\frac{\sqrt{3} b c}{2 b c}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}
$$

Thus, the desired angle $\alpha=30^{\circ}$.
informal_statement:
## Task B-2.3.

Let $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ be the angles of a triangle. If $\frac{\sin ^{2} \gamma+\sin ^{2} \beta-\sin ^{2} \alpha}{\sin \beta \cdot \sin \gamma}=\sqrt{3}$, determine the angle $\alpha$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped Real

/- ## Task B-2.3.

Let $\alpha, \beta$ and $\gamma$ be the angles of a triangle. If $\frac{\sin ^{2} \gamma+\sin ^{2} \beta-\sin ^{2} \alpha}{\sin \beta \cdot \sin \gamma}=\sqrt{3}$, determine the angle $\alpha$. -/
theorem algebra_246872 (α β γ : Real) (h₀ : α + β + γ = π)
  (h₁ : (sin γ ^ 2 + sin β ^ 2 - sin α ^ 2) / (sin β * sin γ) = sqrt 3) :
  α = π / 6 := by

soln_description:
## Solution

The length of the arc of a curve defined by the equation $y=f(x) ; a \leq x \leq b$, is determined by the formula

$$
L=\int_{a}^{b} \sqrt{1+\left(f^{\prime}(x)\right)^{2}} d x
$$

Let's find the derivative of the given function:

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(x)=\left(2+\arcsin \sqrt{x}+\sqrt{x-x^{2}}\right)^{\prime} & =\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-x}} \cdot \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x} \sqrt{1-x}} \cdot(1-2 x)= \\
& =\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x} \sqrt{1-x}}+\frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x} \sqrt{1-x}}-\frac{2 x}{2 \sqrt{x} \sqrt{1-x}}= \\
& =\frac{1}{\sqrt{x} \sqrt{1-x}}-\frac{x}{\sqrt{x} \sqrt{1-x}}= \\
& =\frac{1-x}{\sqrt{x} \sqrt{1-x}}=\sqrt{\frac{1-x}{x}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, using the formula above, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
L & =\int_{1 / 4}^{1} \sqrt{1+\left(\sqrt{\frac{1-x}{x}}\right)^{2}} d x= \\
& =\int_{1 / 4}^{1} \sqrt{1+\frac{1-x}{x}} d x= \\
& =\int_{1 / 4}^{1} \sqrt{\frac{x+1-x}{x}} d x= \\
& =\int_{1 / 4}^{1} \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} d x=\left.2 \sqrt{x}\right|_{1 / 4} ^{1}=2-\frac{2}{\sqrt{4}}=1
\end{aligned}
$$

Source — «http://pluspi.org/wiki/index.php/\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�\�_\�\�
